												Every now and then a mobile developer tries to take their successful, beloved mobile game and bring it to a more traditional gaming platform. These efforts always result in dumpster fires of failure. It isn't that mobile games are necessarily worse than their more traditional counterparts, just that different audiences expect differetn things from their gaming experience. People that want to waste a couple of minutes on the ride to work aren't going to want the same exact thing when they actually sit down and play something in their own free time, and Doodle God is just the latest example of that.Doodle God, however, is just a mess from top to bottom. I don't understand how even mobile gamers enjoyed this. If you took a point-and-click adventure game item combination puzzle, and removed the context, goals, story, fun, and coded it entirely in goat's blood, you'd get Doodle God. You start with four elements, and start combining these elements to make more elements. These elements can then be combined with other elements to make more elements, and these elements can then be used to finally get you to the end goal: making more elements. That's all there is to the game. Rubbing two items together, hoping they work, and then seriously reevaluating where your life went wrong.You may think that combining elements to make more elements (made so you can make more elements) might sound pointless and boring, but you're wrong. It's also frustrating too. Unlike most games where you're combining things, the game doesn't really give you any hints as to what you should be making. The game has you making stuff like octopi and ghouls, but other common items aren't in the game's dictionary. However, the game doesn't actually tell you it wants octopi and ghouls, and you just sort of have to guess. This is fine in the early game when you don't have many objects, but at some point you have over 100 at one time and without the game hinting what the hell it actually wants you to make you just sort of have to guess. Doodle God is that annoying partner you had back in college that always wanted to go out to dinner but wouldn't tell you what he or she wanted until you actually guessed it.And to top it all off, a lot of the combinations don't make sense. Alright, so a warrior and a firearm makes a soldier. I suppose I can see that train of logic. But a fish and knowledge makes an octopus? What the hell does that even mean, Doodle God? "Just gotta keep on reading to the fish...gotta make them an octopus through education... hmm," one of the developers overheard an insane man mumbling to himself on the subway one day and that idea made it into the game somehow. Since some of these combinations were seemingly just pulled out at random from a hat, inevitably you will reach a point where you just need to randomly start combining things and hoping for the best. Or you could just wait until the hints refill and do it that way. Or you can close Doodle God, delete it from your computer, then burn your computer on the off chance some of the awfulness from this title somehow seeped its way onto your harddrive. I'd recommend the third option. Or, the vastly superior option, never buying or downloading this in the first place and doing something better with your time like playing any other game available on Steam, going outside, or sitting perfectly still and allowing your mind to slowly deteriorate. Any of those option are better than ten minutes with Doodle God.

												Let's list every good thing about this game:1: Some item combinations are mildly amusing.2: The art is decent.Okay, done. Here's all the bad things:1: It's a bad mobile port and the entire UI is clearly designed for touchscreen, and plays awfully on a computer2: At least half the game is essentially advertisement for GameFAQs, because the item combinations are so arbitrary as to be impossible without a walkthrough or brute forcing. The only reason that the combinations are as nonsensical as they are was to sell more Hint IAPs, and it makes the game completely unenjoyable.3: There's a few combinations I found which actually had a different result depending on when in the game I combined them - meaning that I actually had to enter the exact same input twice expecting different results to complete the game.4: The game costs $6 despite merely being a port of an IAP-laden port of a sequel of a clone of a flash game from 2004. You could just play the first Doodle God on Kongregate for free and get an identical experience, if not a better one thanks to a UI that was actually designed for the platform they released the game on.5: A significant amount of these are near-identical to other combinations of items so you can't even complete the game without repeating yourself constantly (e.g., there's ~8 types of alcohol, all of which count as different combinations with nearly any material that combines with any alcohol)6: The game has 4 or 5 different gameplay modes, but I honestly can't tell the difference between any of them. The gameplay loop is exactly the same - pick a random thing, rub it against another random thing, hope the developers concocted some story as to how they fit together, and then rinse and repeat. 7: Every time you do luck out and find an arbitrary combination of elements that makes something new, you get thrown out of the combination screen and into a tedious animation of that new object appearing on a globe. This is mildly interesting the first 2 or 3 times. Less so after the 200th. In a game that's already frustratingly slow thanks to an awful UI and necessity of brute force, it just exacerbates the irritance.Just save your money and play the thousands of free flash games that do this much better.

												tldr - don't buy this game, you're better off playing either the free flash version (Doodle Blitz) or the app, which this game is a port of. The developers disgustingly put in microtransactions, asking players to pay for important functions which should be free from the getgo, and in turn stopped Doodle God from being the good game that it should be.Full Review:To be honest, I am pretty disappointed with Doodle God. It is actually just a Steam port of their mobile app. Seeing as how this has a higher asking price, I assumed that the game would already contain the additional useful functions which you had to pay extra for in the app and free flash versions. Appallingly enough, they still aren't made available to you despite the fact that we have paid a higher amount for almost the same game!! The functions that I mentioned are the ability to have repeated reactions disabled and to show which elements still had combinations available. Now, if you have never played any of the games in this series, let me sum up the gameplay briefly: You start off with a particular set of elements, and you combine them in the hopes of creating new ones. As you create new elements, more and more potential combinations are made possible. At first, its easy to keep track of which combos you have already made, but when you have, say, 75 elements, available, it becomes difficult to continue keeping track. After a while, Doodle God becomes less of a game and more like mere tedium. Doodle God is tagged as being casual, but instead of being that it ends up simply brainless. This is largely due to the fact that those aforementioned functions aren't available to us. Had we been given them, the experience would be MUCH more enjoyable.As if asking us to pay for those functions weren't offensive enough, the developers had the audacity to PUT A PRICE ON ADDITIONAL HINTS. Do you really think anyone would pay money for hints when they can just search up solutions/walkthroughs online for FREE?The only difference between this game and the mobile version is the Tournament mode which is not that fun to begin with due to it being buggy. There is no incentive for players to participate because it gives the top ranked players a useless prize, additional hints. I assumed that seeing as how they are selling it for an increased, they would give players access to disabled repeated reactions and the border guides, functions which you would have to pay for on the mobile and free flash versions.I won't deny, there are plenty of clever, funny moments in this game. However, the microtransactions and the withholding of functions that should be free, left a terrible taste in my mouth, despite being a fan of the series. It had the potential to be a nice, light, casual game. Hopefully the developers see our dissatisfaction with this and changes this, because right now, I cannot recommend people to pay full price for this. Just play the app or free flash version if you are REALLY interested. I wouldn't recommend buying this :/

												I became interested in Doodle God because of my job.  I figured any game that could keep a special needs child entertained and quiet (and not poking his neighboring van mates) during an hour long ride home AFTER being coped up in school all day had to be worth looking into.  The game is certainly mind absorbing, with all the combinations of "elements" that can be combined in the main game alone (249 total).  Now add to that all the other "mini" games that can be played.  Hours of entertainment, or at least mind absorbing nullness.     For those who do not know about Doodle God.  It is a game of combining "elements" such fire, human or zombie with other "elements" like water, apple, or internet to make new elements.  In the main game there are 4 stages, ultimately working up to a total of 249 elements.  Some of the combinations are very logical while others are not.  The main game is basically a game of elimination where the player takes a single element and combines it with every other element to see what happens.  Then repeat with a new element.  (Special thanks to MakoSipper and their achievement guide God of Patience.  I am quite certain without this guide I would have never gotten that achievement.)   Beyond the main game there 7 Quests, 14 Artifacts, 11 Puzzles, an on-line Tournament, and an Encyclopedia (a compliation of every element and element combination from all the games (main, quests, artifacts and puzzles).The Quests are specific scenerios such helping Santa build a sleigh or surviving on a desert island.  Artifacts is simply a puzzle where the player takes three elements and combines them to make a particular object like Stonehenge or a Light Saber.  (The best guide for this is Quests & Artifacts by ReivaX.)The Puzzles are more active thinking then simply random combinations.  The player must use the correct combinations to achieve the desired outcome such making a firecracker or a Jack O Lantern. It is easy to make the wrong combinations and get stuck.  If stuck, undo combinations or start again. (I made a visual guide for the Puzzles since there was not one already.)This game is not for everyone, and requires patience, tenacity and perseverance to get through (and/or earn all the achievements which is a different sort of patience, tenacity and perseverance.)

October 30, 2016Doodle God is weird in bad ways. I suppose it's technically a game. Put icons together to make other icons, with some flavor tech thrown in to add humor. JoyBits is at least honest in saying "Mobile. Social. Casual."I can't really talk too much about the game, as it is not inspiring to any degree. It's almost an easy 100% with guides, but the Patience achievement can be finicky.Doodle God is just not fun, and shows the flash/mobile game roots even after purchases have been removed. I feel like the game is aimed at younger kids, but the content doesn't seem appropriate. There are multiple icons related to sex and alcohol, and some flavor text with vulgar words, so I can't imagine many parents would be happy. If the game is for matured gamers, I can't imagine that they will be intellectually or mechanically stimulated. New content (more of the same) may be added, but bigger changes are reserved for mobile sequels (Doodle Kingdom, Devil, 8-bit, etc) available for purchase. I expect those games will be boring bundle fodder, which is where I got my copy. Don't bother at any price.

But that makes perfect sense since if you had unlimited hints, then this would be less of a challenge.The basis of this game is to incrementally combine "elements", which initially are air, fire, water, and earth into other elements, and so on, until you have built up to more complex elements like human and tools.  The game consists of four chapters, where in each you need to form up to a certain number of elements.  What separates chapters is adding an extra special element, as well as being able to combine some elements to form new ones not previously available.These combinations are not random.  They are a combination of logic, intuition and humor.  Sometimes you can form the same element multiple times in different ways.  Some elements like philospher's stone, have a property to "undo" other elements.  For instance, it combined with vampire, gives human, since vampire was the combination of blood and human.However, I will say the longer you play and the more elements you have at your disposal, the more difficult it can be to make any progress without getting a hint.  There are primarily three types of hints for the main game.  The first, which is rare, simply gives you a new element by combining two existing ones.  I don't like this one since it is just telling you the answer basically.   The second, which is the best, gives you two  groups from which then you know that you get a new element by combining an element from each.  At worst, you can just go through all pairing possibilities until you stumble onto a new element.  This hint recharges each 10 minutes, so it pretty much guarantees it will advance you in the game.  The last hint, which is the main one to use, is that it simply shows a new element that can be formed.  Just by knowing what one can be, gives you the chance to try and figure out what you can combine that could give that particular element.FInally, this game also has various mini games, such as puzzles, where you need to build up to a final element, like Christmas tree, not available in the normal main game, through a sequence of combinations from limited initiali materials.  In these puzzles, some of the combinations you have seen, and others you haven't.  All in all, I find this to be a fairly polished game.  Compared to the mobile version, I prefer the Steam version since it is more clear how many more elements are left to discover for a group, plus additional features such as an encyclopedia of discovered elements and the quotes that can go along with each as they are discovered.  Is this game worth $6?  By no means, but if you can get it part of a bundle as I did, or on sale for $1 or $2, then it is worth a little bit of time and money.

												Having read other reviews, it seems that the main criticisms levelled against Doodle god are that a) it contains microtransactions even though you've already paid for it, and b) it's pretty much a port of the mobile version, which is cheaper (albeit containing even more microtransactions)I must say however, that even though you can pay for hints to help you solve the game's puzzles, it's by no means necessary to do so. The hints recharge at a fairly decent rate and so you basically get them for free anyway, paying for them is just a way of hurrying things along and so there's no need to shell out any more cash than you've already spent.True, there is a cheaper version for mobile devices, although I can't verify that it's exactly the same... From what I can surmise the Steam version contains a bit more content and doesn't require you to pay any where near as much for what you basically should already get in a bought game.The above issues aside, Doodle god is actually a pretty decent example of this type of setup. It looks great, presentation is superb and playing it is a pleasure. I love the way that as you progress, your creations start to appear on a nicely illustrated planet and the game consistently rewards you when you get things right. The music is relaxing and never grates on the ears. The only thing I would say though is that there is no volume control, no excuses for that really!!There's quite a bit of gameplay to keep you going, the main quest will probably take you 8 hours and then there are extra quests to do which will probably take you a few more. The puzzles for the most part are fairly logical but some can be a bit off the wall.. For instance Corpse + Electricity = Death metal?? I mean, I get it but.. I wouldn't automagically think to make that one.. It is a game that is suited to playing in bursts of about an hour at a time, but it's pretty addictive and you'll probably find yourself going back to it to catch 'em all.Overall it's quite a decent game for the price and I'll give it 6.8/10, I've had a lot of fun with it, but it's marred by annoyingly unnecessary microtransactions and a lack of volume control. If the developers change these aspects then the figure will rise.

												Doodle God is an interesting and fun puzzle game. The puzzles and combinations are generally good. Some combinations don't really make sense sometimes, but you'll have that.When compared to the version I played on Android a while back, some of the additions for this version can be a little annoying. The world view frequently pops up, taking you away from play in the main game. There are a lot more combinations and groups here, which makes it endlessly more difficult to find something specific if you haven't been using it since nearly the beginning of the game. It also doesn't help that things get moved around in the last section of the game. The only thing that saves this is the search, but the search goes away as soon as you click. It would be nice if I could keep the search open on both sides and drag directly from them.The quests, when done right, will tell a neat little story, such as saving a princess or getting stranded on an island and getting rescued (if you play that one right). They're a nice addition. The added content in general sometimes feels like it's purely to extend gameplay though. It does mean that there's a lot more stuff to play around with and discover in the game.Yes, it offers microtransactions, that you would have to turn on to be able to get. It's only for people that don't want to solve the puzzles. You can get the same stuff by just playing, or if you don't feel like discovering stuff on your own, you can use a walkthrough, which there are many out there for Doodle God.There are several things I don't like about the game, but at the core, it's still a fun and interesting game. The good of the game really does outshine the mild annoyances I find in it, so it gets a thumbs up from me.

												Doodle God is a simplistic puzzle game where you, as God, must create the universe.  You start with the four basic elements of nature (fire, earth, wind and water) and by combining them you must create items ranging from oceans, volcanoes, rocks, plants and animals to humans, tools and weapons and eventually machines such as automobiles and rockets. The developer markets this game as requiring logic and ingenuity in order to succeed , but it's really little more than a guessing game where you'll frequently find yourself using trial-and-error to find the right combination of items needed to progress. I do believe that Doodle God was a great idea when it was first released as a free online game many years ago, but I don't believe this version offers enough additional content to justify the price.
